document_title: Erectile dysfunction: Causes, symptoms, treatment and prevention
subsection_content:
Most erectile dysfunction is related to vascular, neurological, psychological and hormonal disorders. Drug use is also a cause. Primary erectile dysfunction has a low rate and is caused by abnormalities or congenital abnormalities of the body.
Psychological factors play an important role in causing erectile dysfunction, so they are often considered in all cases of erectile dysfunction. The patient may experience depression or anxiety, stress in personal life, feelings of guilt or fear of not wanting to have sex... These psychological factors can be completely resolved by a doctor or doctor. Psychologist, mentally relieving patients.
70% of erectile dysfunction cases come from the following physical causes: (3)
Diseases that affect blood vessels and limit blood flow to the penis such as: diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure or increased blood cholesterol... The most common is penile cavernous atherosclerosis, caused by suctioning medications and diabetes. Atherosclerosis, accompanied by natural degeneration, reduces the ability of arteries to relax and smooth muscle in the vessel walls, reducing the amount of blood entering the penis. Use of trazodone, heroin, alcohol, and sickle cell disease can cause penile fibrosis, which reduces the blood flow needed to the penis for an erection.; Causes that reduce nerve conduction from the central nervous system to the penis such as: multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, spinal cord pathology, peripheral and autonomic nervous diseases.; Endocrine disorders: decreased testosterone in the blood (male menopause), increased prolactin secreted by the pituitary gland, hypothyroidism...; Complications of pelvic surgery such as cancer treatment, prostatectomy, radical cystectomy; transurethral resection of the prostate; rectal cancer surgery...; Trauma: brain, spinal cord, pelvis...; Some medications to treat high blood pressure, diuretics, antiarrhythmics, antidepressants, sedatives...; Depression.; Prolonged pelvic pressure (eg, cycling too much)
